definition: big/huge/large/major/great/wide/deep/older (than)/oldest/eldest/greatly/very much/(dialect) father/father's elder or younger brother
knife/blade/single-edged sword/cutlass/CL:把[ba3]/(slang) dollar (loanword)/classifier for sets of one hundred sheets (of paper)/classifier for knife cuts or stabs

sentences.english: He would slay the system, like the Terminator.
sentences.chinese: 他會像終結者那樣大刀闊斧改革不正常的機制。

sentences.english: Burdened with no fardel of the past, he has boldly taken the initiative.
sentences.chinese: 但是他無歷史包袱，以大刀闊斧決斷爭取主動。

sentences.english: He knows voters are clamoring for decisive action to stop the country's slide into economic malaise.
sentences.chinese: 他知道選民要求政府採取大刀闊斧的行動挽救經濟。

sentences.english: But the heavy hand of the government can be stifling here.
sentences.chinese: 但是政府這種大刀闊斧的做法可能會適得其反。

sentences.english: You don't need to take huge steps, just smalls.
sentences.chinese: 你不必要大刀闊斧，只是需要平時小小的投資。
國會大刀闊斧地削減預算。

sentences.english: Instead, Mr Razaleigh's candidacy was quashed by party chiefs.
sentences.chinese: 但是政黨首領卻大刀闊斧，削去了拉沙理的候選資格。

definition: to take turns/to work by roster
to blindly follow suit (idiom)/to imitate slavishly/to do what everyone else is doing
plethora of things to tackle/multitude of loose ends/very complicated/chaotic
to show one's colors/to have a clear-cut stand (idiom)
to judge the hour and size up the situation/to take stock
(of a pendulum) to stop swinging/(of work, production, activities etc) to come to a halt/to be suspended/to be canceled/shutdown/(sports) lockout
bring order out of chaos/set to rights things which have been thrown into disorder
to adjust one's head and turn one's face (idiom); cosmetic changes/Despite superficially new policies, the substance remains unchanged.
lit. to see a gap and stick in a needle (idiom); fig. to make use of every second and every inch
